articles.title: Tempo: An Easier Way to Work with Dates
articles.description: We think they nailed their own summary: ‚ÄúA collection of utilities for working with the native Date object ‚Äî an important distinction from other libraries that provide custom date primitives. Under the hood, Tempo mines Intl.DateTimeFormat to extract complex data like timezones offsets and locale aware date formats, giving you a simple API to format, parse, and manipulate dates.‚Äù Fantastic docs, too.
articles.author: FormKit

articles.title: LLRT (Low Latency Runtime): Amazon's New JS¬†Runtime
articles.description: Amazon has open sourced a runtime entirely focused on fast startups ‚Äì something that‚Äôs useful for ephemeral use cases like serverless (*cough* AWS Lambda). It uses Fabrice Bellard‚Äôs QuickJS as the underlying engine, so has almost full ES2023 spec support out of the box.
articles.author: Amazon Web Services Labs

articles.title: The Node.js Valentine's Day Security Releases
articles.description: Security releases had been expected to land in the past week for Node and they‚Äôre now here as v21.6.2 (Current), v20.11.1 (LTS), and v18.19.1 (LTS). They include fixes for a variety of vulnerabilities, including some high severity ones involving HTTP-based DoS attacks and privilege escalation.
articles.author: Rafael Gonzaga and Marco Ippolito

articles.title: Union, Intersection, Difference, and More Coming to JavaScript Sets
articles.description: Set was introduced back in ECMAScript 2015 (a.k.a. ES6) but only had some basic methods built-in. Phil looks at what sets can do and what new features are on the way.
articles.author: Phil Nash

articles.title: Immutable Array Updates with Array.prototype.with
articles.description: How to use this new, widely supported method to update an array without mutating the original array.
articles.author: Jad Joubran

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†So You Think You Know Git..
articles.description: GitHub co-founder Scott Chacon gave a spirited talk at FOSDEM 2024 digging into many interesting parts of git, as well as a few GitHub bits. If you‚Äôd prefer to read rather than watch, he has some blog posts covering it all too.
articles.author: Scott Chacon

articles.title: An Example of Creating a React App with Google Sheets as a¬†Backend
articles.description: Not as unorthodox an approach as you might think.
articles.author: Musthaq Ahamad

articles.title: Safely Accessing the DOM with Angular SSR
articles.description: Learn how to safely use the DOM together with SSR in Angular.
articles.author: Gerald Monaco (Google)

articles.title: Peggy 4.0: A Parser Generator for JavaScript
articles.description: Produces fast parsers with good error reporting. Use it to process complex data or computer languages and build transformers, interpreters, compilers, and similar tools. The online demo is pretty effective. The official successor to PEG.js.
articles.author: Majda, Hildebrand, and Contributors

articles.title: vue-metamorph 1.0: A Codemod Framework for Vue.js Projects
articles.description: A developer needed to make a large number of small changes to a variety of Vue components and built this tool to help. GitHub repo.
articles.author: UnrefinedBrain

articles.title: canvas-size 2.0: Determine Max Area, Height, Width, and Custom Dimensions of HTML Canvases
articles.description: The Canvas element is broadly supported across browsers but there are differences in its size limitations, which this library can determine for you. GitHub repo.
articles.author: John Hildenbiddle

articles.title: txiki.js: A Small Yet Powerful JavaScript Runtime
articles.description: Standing on the shoulders of QuickJS and libuv.
articles.author: Sa√∫l Ibarra Corretg√©

articles.title: Svelte Stepper: Build Animated Stepped Flows with Svelte
articles.description: You can add and customize props on the component to adjust the number of steps and transition duration, among other features. See a simple but neat demo here.
articles.author: Jason Efstathiou

articles.description: You know how features and proposals for the ECMAScript language pass through a multi-stage process with the TC39 committee? There's a new stage: stage 2.7! The new stage is what 3 used to be with 3 now having extra testing requirements.
Talking of TC39, here's the latest state of different proposals covered at the recent 100th TC39 meeting.
There have been some updates on the state of Express and suggested plans for Express 5.0, 6.0 and 7.0.

Google has unveiled the newest version of its Gemini AI model. Of particular note is its support for 1 million tokens of context, as shown in ‚ñ∂Ô∏è this example working upon the entirety of three.js's source code (~820k tokens).
A new JavaScript registry is on the way called jsr. Waitlist only, for now.
Vue.js DevTools 6.6 ‚Äì Now with a new UI.
Hono 4.0 ‚Äì The lightweight, runs-anywhere Web framework takes a big step forward.
JointJS 4.0 ‚Äì The powerful interactive diagramming/flowchart library now has no external dependencies.
Astro 4.4, Angular 17.2, Billboard.js 3.11

articles.title: Apple 'Broke' Web Apps in iOS 17 Beta; Still Hasn't Fixed¬†Them
articles.description: There‚Äôs been plenty of chatter about App Store changes, and PWAs in iOS 17 this week ‚Äî all coming as a result of upcoming EU enforcement of the Digital Markets Act. This PWA bust is a change in the current beta, and the overall deadline for DMA compliance is in March ‚Äî so things may change yet, but right now it‚Äôs not looking great for all things PWA on iOS for those in the EU.
articles.author: Thomas Claburn

articles.title: CSS Mixins & Functions Explainer
articles.description: Following a recent update from the CSS Working Group, Miriam captures the overall state of the conversation on developing CSS-native mixins and functions, including looking at how they would differ from existing pre-processors, and what extra functionality (or limitations) could come with such a browser level approach. A thorough, detailed overview.
articles.author: Miriam Suzanne

articles.title: Mozilla Downsizes As It Refocuses on Firefox and AI
articles.description: With a new interim CEO in place, Mozilla is making some major changes to its product strategy, including bringing ‚Äútrustworthy AI into Firefox‚Äù ü§®.
articles.author: Frederic Lardinois (TechCrunch)

articles.title: The Performance Inequality Gap in 2024
articles.description: Just how much HTML, CSS, and JavaScript can we afford to use in our projects? Alex digs in and notes that the answer is ‚Äúmore than in years past, but much less than frontend developers are burdening users with‚Äù.
articles.author: Alex Russell

articles.title: Things Frequently Heard in My Beginning Frontend Web Development¬†Class
articles.description: What could we learn from entry-level students in frontend web development? Geoff opines that it's newcomers to the space who ask the most intriguing questions and who make ‚Äúconnections that those of us who have spent years on the front end may have never considered‚Äù.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: Can Generative AI Help Write Accessible Code?
articles.description: An experiment in asking three, free generative AI tools (Gemini, ChatGPT, and Fix My Code) some typical questions about accessible code.
articles.author: L√©onie Watson

articles.title: The New CSS Math: pow(), sqrt(), and Exponential Friends
articles.description: These CSS functions are now available in the latest versions of Chrome, Edge, Firefox, and Safari. The pow() function mirrors the Math.pow() JavaScript functionality (for specifying how many times to multiply a number by itself). The sqrt() function is for finding the square root of a number. Dan shares details on these, where you might use them, and more. Handy stuff.
articles.author: Daniel Wilson

articles.title: How I Solved My Font Rendering Problem
articles.description: A quick fix for a variable font rendering issue on iOS.
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: Nested Dark Mode via CSS Proximity
articles.description: Jonathan notes that ‚Äòinheritance‚Äô is probably the more accurate title here, but ‚Äòproximity‚Äô helped them define the concept better.
articles.author: Jonathan Dallas

articles.title: Brutalist Web Design
articles.description: Guidelines for web design that adhere to the tenets and ethos of brutalism ‚Äî a term more often associated with architecture. However, David notes that it can apply to other forms of construction, including web design.
articles.author: David Copeland

articles.title: Velvette: Making It Easier to Author CSS View Transitions
articles.description: A small library that adds some features ostensibly missing from the View Transitions API (i.e. temporary classes during transition, unique name generation, and others).
articles.author: Noam Rosenthal

articles.title: CheerpJ 3.0: A WebAssembly JVM to Run Real-World Apps in the¬†Browser
articles.description: CheerpJ 3.0, a state-of-the-art WebAssembly JVM that runs real-world Java applications in the browser, is now available, although note that it‚Äôs a commercial project (but free for personal use).
articles.author: Leaning Technologies

articles.title: Tailwind CSS Button Collection: Click-to-Copy Animated Buttons
articles.description: A gallery of more than 60 hover, click, and loading button effects built using Tailwind classes, some simple and others more unconventional.
articles.author: Julien Thibeaut

articles.title: CSS Neural Network (Number Detection)
articles.description: This is kinda wild, and it feels like magic (but really it's just math!‚Ñ¢). You 'draw' in a number and the output updates with its best guess (‚ñ∂Ô∏è Quick video demo). It didn‚Äôt work in Safari for me, but seems ok elsewhere. (The true 'magic' here is in the use of SCSS to create a lot of boilerplate ‚Äì well worth looking through, and then looking at the resulting CSS in DevTools.)
articles.author: Bali Balo
